title: Phrack Pro-Phile VI: The Nightstalker
historical_context: This article provides insight into the early days of hacking and phreaking, highlighting influential figures in the community.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This article profiles The Nightstalker, a significant figure in the hacking and phreaking communities, detailing his early experiences with telecommunications, hacking, and his views on the hacker identity.
summary:
In this engaging profile, Taran King introduces The Nightstalker, a prominent figure in the early hacking and phreaking scene. The Nightstalker began his journey in 1971, inspired by an Esquire article on blue boxes, and quickly became involved in hacking after discovering ARPAnet at MIT. His contributions to the telecommunications field include assisting in the development of the ALTAIR 8080B and participating in classic phreaking tricks. The article paints a vivid picture of his life, interests, and memorable experiences, including encounters with notable figures like Steve Wozniak and Bill Gates.

The Nightstalker expresses his disdain for the modern interpretation of the term 'hacker,' criticizing those who misuse the label without understanding the systems they exploit. He emphasizes the importance of genuine knowledge and skill in hacking, distinguishing between true hackers and those who engage in criminal activities. His reflections on the societal perceptions of technology and the commercialization of computers provide a thought-provoking commentary on the evolution of hacker culture. Overall, this article serves as a fascinating glimpse into the mindset of one of the early pioneers in the field.
